Study Tips for MATH 1023

Rule of Thumb for all university MATH courses (not just 1023)

Put continuous effort in the course throughout the semester! Understand all fundamental concepts by regularly attending lectures, reading lecture notes, and discussing with teaching staff and classmates. Develop your mathematical maturity and problem-solving skills through exercises and homework. Don't expect you can skip all lectures or exercises, and then "爆seed" by intensive/overnight revision the day before the exams! It is impossible to absorb all course materials in just one night.

(see the meaning of "爆seed" here (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.)

Be critical

Don't just learn math superficially by memorizing formulae or by following homework solutions blindly. University level math, especially this honor course, emphasizes much more on logical thinking than high school math. Always ask for the reasons and make sure you are able to justify every step. Don't feel satisfied by just asking "how", but ask also "why", "what if", "under what conditions", "what's good", etc. To get started, you should first change the mindset that learning math is not about memorizing or doing routine calculations.

Be logical

When you learn a theorem, don't just look at the "formula part". It is more important to keep in mind the necessary conditions and hypotheses in order to apply those theorem. For instance, look at the statement:
LaTeX: \displaystyle\text{If } \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = L \text { and } \lim_{x \to a} g(x) = M, \text{ then } \lim_{x \to a} f(x) + g(x) = L + M. If  lim x → a   f ( x ) = L  and  lim x → a   g ( x ) = M ,  then  lim x → a   f ( x ) + g ( x ) = L + M .  
Many high school students would just memorize the rule that:
LaTeX: \displaystyle{\lim_{x\to a} f(x) + g(x) = \lim_{x \to a} f(x) + \lim_{x \to a}g(x)} lim x → a   f ( x ) + g ( x ) = lim x → a   f ( x ) + lim x → a   g ( x )   
but ignore the assumption that both LaTeX: \displaystyle\lim_{x \to a} f(x) \text{ and } \lim_{x \to a} g(x) lim x → a   f ( x )  and  lim x → a   g ( x )   have to exist (and finite) in order to make use of this rule.

In this course, you should always pay attention to the assumptions and conditions of a theorem. Ask yourself whether the theorem would fail if these conditions are not met. Furthermore, such a condition or assumption must be used somewhere in the proof, ask yourself where this condition appears in the proof and why it is needed!

Be a good listener

While my lectures will be based on the lecture notes, they are not merely the "audio" version of the notes. By just reading the lecture notes, you may only learn how to do math, but in lectures/tutorials you will learn why math is done that way, and in the long-run you will also learn the way of thinking of the instructor and TAs. Therefore, try to focus on listening and thinking during class. Taking notes (blindly) may hinder your thoughts. All blackboard notes written during a lecture will be recorded in a PDF that you can check it up later.

Work smart (not just work hard)

Learning mathematics -- just like learning "九陰真經" -- requires intensive practicing, deciphering, but not just passively by quick reading (though mathematics is not like "葵花寶典" that you need to "sacrifice" in order to learn it). Do relevant exercises soon after a lecture. Work hard and do more exercises than assigned; but work smart -- don't just do exercises of the same type over and over again. After you feel confident with basic and routine problems, go deeper on more structured and thought-provoking problems to broaden your knowledge and skills. Don't just do ALL exercises in ONE book, but do SOME exercises in SEVERAL books. Kenneth Ross's book on Elementary Analysis is a good one. Some structured problems of the deceased HKALE Pure Math were very well written -- that you can learn something new in a "guided" way.

Learn from people

Math is not fun if you learn it alone. Form a small group (such as with your highschool-mates, o'camp group-mates) to study the course together. Whenever you find difficulty in a homework problem, discuss it with your friends first to exchange ideas. If the problem is still not resolved, ask instructors and TAs for hint. If you are afraid of finding the instructor and TAs alone, go together with your group.

reviews.comment_content: Before the midterm, the course covers the rigorous definition of limits (That is how to prove for example that the limit as x approaches a of x^2 = a^2 using well defined mathematical formulations and being rigorous while doing so). This part emphasized proofs and professor Hu Proved everything he wrote, and I mean everything. You won't be expected to repeat his proofs in the exam but you are expected to understand them since you can use a similar way to prove other questions he might ask. Also, he covers all the differentiation rules and again proofs the product rule, quotient rule, etc. After the midterm, he focused on on the applications such as optimization problems, sketching graphs, intermediate value theorem, mean value theorem, L'hospital rule, local and global minima and maxima, concavity, etc. Overall, the course has a really rewarding content and I definitely recommend taking it if 1) you don't care about the grade that much and 2) if you are going to major in maths. The course has improved my mathematical maturity so much and made me think of most stuff in terms of their proofs and definitions, definitely a well constructed calculus course and is almost the same difficulty (if not harder) than other calculus courses in other US universities such as MIT and Caltech, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Hu, for me is one of the best mathematics professors that ever thaught me in my life. He has many famous sentences such as: "You don't know the definition, you get a big 0" and "Your intuition tells you that this limit is 0? well my intuition tells me that YOU get a 0" and finally "Analysis is a hard subject, every year at least 3 people commit suicide in MIT because of analysis:". Professor Hu teaching is extremely funny and laid down and you can sense he enjoys what he does, he focuses on two things: LOGIC and DEFINITION, if you lack one in your answer then you're getting a big 0. For example, the limit as x approaches infinity of (1/(x+4)) = 0 since the denominator grows to infinity and 1 divided by a very big number is 0. if you write this in the exam you get a 0. To get the mark, you can either 1) proof that the limit of 1/x+4 is indeed 0 by the DEFINITION or use logic and algebraic manipulation to write 1/x+4 as (1/x)/(1+4/x). since we know limit as x approaches infinity of 1/x = limit of 4/x  = 0 and by the continuity of the polynomials, the limit is 0/(1+0) = 0/1 = 0 therefore we conclude the limit is 0. See how many steps we needed to show the limit of such an easy limit is 0? you have to follow similar arguments in ALL your answers or else, a big 0.

A final word about the TA (Xilin Li), this is arguably one of the best TAs in the maths department, the guy is very nice, he explains things thoroughly and you can meet him after class and he would even explain FULL lessons to you after class if you need it, he is always at the maths support center most of the time and I honestly wouldn't have gotten my A- without this guy. Seriously a life saver.

Also, for the lecture notes, review the attachments below, study from these notes since they are much harder and rigorous than the Stewart calculus book. everyone studies from it.
reviews.comment_grading:

He told me you should take it butt you might get a C or C+ even if you're good because these guys are really good, I ended up in the end getting an A- (Even though I regard myself to be exceptional in mathematics and I ranked in the top 1.8 percentile in the maths exam in my country) and I studied a lot! So if this tells you something, its that the course is full of good people, and in the end, around 40% got A- or higher and I barely hit the A- level. So be very careful if you need to maintain a certain gpa for your scholarship, I know you might really think you are very good in maths, but so did I and you're going to have to work your ass off just to get an A.

Basically a combination of MATH1013, MATH2033(MATH2043?) without integration, and about half of MATH2001.

Professor Ip will go through the lecture notes and 12 worksheets with us during lectures, and the TA will go through the 13 tutorial worksheets in the tutorials.

The content is as interesting as the difficulty of this course. Instead of just knowing how to do limits, differentiation, and remember certain theorems (what taught in 1013), I can actually know the reasoning and proofs behind.
As a local DSE student with neither math competition experience nor self-learned everything, I did feel extreme pain switching from M2 style computation-based math to MATH 1023 style rigorousness. However, it is quite satisfying once you can understand the theorems reasonably well (Doesn't need A+ level understanding to feel this satisfaction), basically opening a new world to you and make you view mathematics differently.

Slight criticism though:
The amount of content and level of difficulty (especially for Professor Ip's years) is a bit too much for a year 1 3-credit course.

What's special about this course is that it emphasizes on mathematical rigor, i.e. every statement should be precisely defined or logically sound (up to some assumptions); which means the MATH1023 will focus on these points:
· Motivation + Observations
· Conceptual Understanding
· Logical Definitions
· Theorems (+Proofs)
· Examples & Applications.

And as you can see, it is very different than MATH1012 or 1013 since they are both mostly focused on computations,which is why the course is highly recommended to those who are planning to do a maths major (specifically pure maths) or even doing theoretical physics.

This course is very different than school maths because it exposes you to the world of proofs and conceptual understanding of math, but it gives you a great learning experience that you won't find in any other course.

Syllabus (Easy:🔷, hard:🔶) (Relative difficulty, all chapters are very hard compared with MATH 1013)

🔶 Chapter 1: Sequence and Limit
🔷 1.1 Limit of Sequence
🔶 1.2 Rigorous Definition of Sequence Limit
🔶 1.3 Criterion for Convergence
🔷 1.4 Infinity
🔷 1.5 Limit of Function
🔶 1.6 Rigorous Definition of Function Limit
🔶 1.7 Continuity

🟥 Midterm exam 🟥

🔶 Chapter 2: Differentiation
🔶 2.1 Linear Approximation

🔷 2.3 Application of Linear Approximation
🔶 2.4 Mean Value Theorem
🔶 2.5 High Order Approximation
🔶 2.6 Application of High Order Approximation
🔶 2.7 Numerical Application (Newton's Method was taught in MATH 1024)

🟥 Final exam 🟥

As summarized by Prof. Ip in the first lecture, this is an introductory course to Math analysis in disguise. For people without a solid math background, e.g. Math Olympiad, the gap from high school math (e.g. DSE Math Core and M2) to the rigorousness in this course is very large, so be prepared to take some time to get used to it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
----------------------------- 𝐋𝐄𝐂𝐓𝐔𝐑𝐄𝐒 -----------------------------

The teaching is very concise and clear, but the speed is very fast. His English accent is good enough for us to follow, and he knows Cantonese as well. You are free to ask him questions after the lecture. There is usually a 5 min break in the middle of a lecture, so your brain can take a rest.

The handwriting is done on GoodNotes with screen recording. If you cannot follow the pace, you can review the lecture by watching the video.

The course content follows mainly Yan Min's notes, but occasionally there will be extra content with supplementary notes. Besides, there will be 1 worksheet per 1-2 lessons that demonstrates some approaches to easier problems.

---------------------------- 𝐓𝐔𝐓𝐎𝐑𝐈𝐀𝐋𝐒 ----------------------------

There is 1 tutorial per week, demonstrating some approaches to very difficult problems, a lot with long solutions that won't appear in homework or exams. However, I think more explanation can be done on how the solutions are achieved, instead of leaving us the impression that only experienced math students can come up with the solutions.

------------------- 𝐅𝐈𝐍𝐀𝐋 𝐑𝐄𝐕𝐈𝐄𝐖 𝐒𝐄𝐒𝐒𝐈𝐎𝐍 -------------------

Before the final exam, there will be a final review session revisiting the concepts, demonstrating some problems, and going through the cheat sheet.
reviews.comment_grading:
------------------------------ 𝐆𝐑𝐀𝐃𝐈𝐍𝐆 ------------------------------

Take the maximum mark such that the total is 100%:

Homework 20%
Midterm 10%-40%
Final 40%-70%

This means you can save your midterm with your final, but not vice versa. Therefore, make sure you put enough effort into preparing for the final exam.

The grade is decent. A range is given to people with 60% total marks or above, though I was sadly 1.25 marks from A-. You secure a B+ if you are above the mean.

-------------------------- 𝐁𝐎𝐍𝐔𝐒 𝐏𝐎𝐈𝐍𝐓𝐒 --------------------------

The homework offers a bonus course point of 0.2 by submitting a LaTeX-generated .pdf file and the original .tex file instead of handwriting. Therefore, you can get a total of 2 total course marks (without the *20% for homework). I think it is worth the time to type LaTeX, as the 2 course marks may be saving you for a higher grade.

You can also earn a bonus course point of 0.2 by finding and reporting a typo in Yan Min's lecture notes, homework, or homework solutions, capped at 2 points. Yan Min's notes contain a decent amount of typos, especially in computation steps, but hard to find in my opinion since the notes are quite long. In contrast, I think typos are easier to be found in Ivan's homework solutions. Some easy ones are missing a "d/dx" and missing a limit symbol.

There was also 1 bonus mark given by simply asking a question for the review session.

With the highest possible bonus course points of 5, you can get one subgrade higher, so they are worth the time completely.

------------------------------- 𝐄𝐗𝐀𝐌𝐒 -------------------------------

The midterm and final exams are extremely difficult, you will feel like vomiting blood during the exams. The exams kick off with a very tricky question (What is the name of the mathematician in the portrait?) (What is the meaning of some weird notation?). Then, there are a few short questions, which are already quite difficult for normal people like me.

Then, they are followed by 2-3 computation questions which are where most people get points from. Each is worth around 10 points. For your reference, midterm has limit computations that require you to apply basic limit knowledge like sinx/x->1 as x->0 and Squeeze Theorem, while final has limit computations that require you to apply the Taylor series (very ugly and tedious). Do not use a calculator to estimate the limit as the value may be extremely large.

Afterward, there are 2 long problems with around 4 parts each. These are the most difficult questions that I usually don't know how to do. But by writing something, regardless of correctness, the lenient T.A.s may give at least 1 mark. You can write down the approach to a problem if you failed to work out the exact details, and you will usually get more than half of the marks.

------------------------ 𝐆𝐑𝐀𝐃𝐄 𝐑𝐄𝐋𝐄𝐀𝐒𝐄 ------------------------

Finally, the final exam result and letter grades are quickly released within 24 hours after the final exam, so don't check your result if you think it may affect your performance in other final exams.
reviews.comment_workload:
--------------------------- 𝐇𝐎𝐌𝐄𝐖𝐎𝐑𝐊 ---------------------------

As a student who got 5** in DSE Math Core and 5* in M2, the workload was like an 8-credit course. But given this is an honor course, I would give the workload a D.

There were a total of 10 homework. Each homework would be released each week, containing 4 compulsory long problems and 1 optional problem with 2-4 parts each. But the deadline was usually 2 weeks later, meaning there was a week of buffer in case you cannot finish it within the first week.

The homework problems require a lot of thinking. Therefore, it's better to form groups to work on the homework, as lots of times, you wouldn't be able to come up with a solution. Usually, the solution only takes not more than 5 steps, so if your unsuccessful attempt is overly complicated, you may be in the wrong direction.

It took me around 5 days to complete one homework at the beginning of the course, and it gradually reduced to 3 days per week as I got used to the rigorousness.

However, the homework was very rewarding, not only because they were intellectually stimulating, but compared to MATH 1013 difficulty, you can have a good grasp of the concepts and computations in the topic, but it was completely not enough for handling Ivan's exams.

-------------------------- 𝐁𝐎𝐍𝐔𝐒 𝐏𝐎𝐈𝐍𝐓𝐒 --------------------------

The homework offers a bonus course point of 0.2 by submitting a LaTeX-generated .pdf file and the original .tex file instead of handwriting. This also takes a lot of time, usually within 1 day. I recommend using the online platform Overleaf - https://overleaf.com for its good editor (e.g. highlight brackets, the drop-down list for commands) and auto-save function. If your eyesight is not that good, you can use Mathcha - https://mathcha.io as it is a live LaTeX editor, i.e. you can directly edit the preview of math expressions with LaTeX instead of typing LaTeX code and then compiling it for preview.

If you are a perfectionist, do not fixate on the beauty of LaTeX, make sure you put enough effort into other courses and balance time well while you take this beast.

reviews.comment_content:
Content before midterm focuses on the rigorous definition of limit of sequence and function so you should make sure that you are extremely familiar with the ε-δ language and capable of writing proofs instead of simply computing. This is quite different from what we have learnt in high school maths so we have a hard time at the beginning of the course to understand all the content completely.
Soon after the midterm we started the second chapter of the textbook, which is written by professor Yan Min and prof. Xiong just keep saying that the textbook is very good and strongly recommend us to do all exercises in it. After the midterm we focus on differentiation. Content is quite similar to the HKALE syllabus (except Taylor series was seemed to be excluded since 1994) but slightly more in depth because proofs will be taught in most circumstances.
The content is quite useful for those who are interested in major in maths, especially pure maths, since the content in the course is simply introduction to real analysis which you will encounter in year2 if you take MATHS2043.

reviews.author: Doraemon
reviews.title: Challenging but well-structured and rigorous
reviews.comment_content:
The course mainly focuses on limits and differentiation. Major topics covered are the epsilon-delta definition of limits, the convergence of sequences, L'Hopital's rule, and Taylor's expansion. Unlike MATH1013 or high school mathematics, proofs are more emphasized in this course. The course content is similar to what was required in Pure Mathematics of the former HKALE exam.

This course is recommended to students who intend to pursue a research or academic career in Mathematics, OR those who have background knowledge about single-variable calculus. If you registered this course ONLY because you met the prerequisite (HKDSE M2 5 or above), you will have a very hard time studying this course.

No textbook from the market is required. The course covers the first two chapters of the textbook Calculus written by Prof. Min Yan.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Xiong simply read the textbook, copied some examples on it, and delivered the most basic material in his lectures. Far from adequate to complete your homework or excel in exams. However, he is a kind instructor who is glad to respond to your questions.

Thus, it may be a bit more efficient to read the textbook yourself without attending lectures and find him during his office hours only if you encounter some questions when doing self-study.

The grading policy is as follows:

Homework 10% (10 assignments in total, each worth 1%)
Mid-term 30%
Final 60%

As the grades from the Math Dept grading system are announced according to the tutorial section, below are the statistics for mid-term and final exams for my tutorial section only:

Mid-term:
Mean=76.40/100

Final:
Mean=84.85/100

Overall:
Mean=82.20/100
reviews.comment_workload:
Not as heavy as expected.

A piece of written homework with about 6 to 8 questions is assigned every week. In each homework, there are usually standard questions which you can complete as long as you attended lectures or read through the textbook. The remaining half will require much more thinking than what was needed to complete your high school homework. As a mathematics lover, I do enjoy thinking on those more difficult problems. But do expect that you have to spend hours on just one question on the homework.

For exams, I would say both the mid-term and final exams are pretty standard, so I believe that you can score pretty well as long as you have done the exercise. Though Prof. Xiong recommended us to do ALL the exercise in Prof. Yan's textbook, I have NOT done so because there are really too many repetitive questions in the textbook. Just do enough so that you can understand the concept and get familiar with the computations. Not worthwhile to do all if taken into account the law of diminishing marginal return.

reviews.author: xdlok
reviews.title: Good grade course if you are good in the first place
reviews.comment_content:
Before midterm:(Rigorous) definition of limit of sequence, sandwich theorem, monotone convergence theorem, Cauchy Sequence, (rigorous) definition of function limits

After midterm: Continuity, IVT; Differentiation, linear approximation, implicit differentiation, MVT, L'Hopital's Rule, taylor series, higher derivative test, concavity and Jensen's Inequality.

    (Almost) Everything is derived from scratch so no prior knowledge is needed (in the sense that it won't help), but mathematical maturity is a must, and you will definitely develop that from homeworks and tutorials.

    This course really encourages thinking the logic and proof behind everything instead of doing boring computations (we do have some though).  We started by assuming only the most basic rules (like arithmetic rule of limits), and then use the rigorous definition to build up everything. It makes you think twice on any seemingly easy question, and think of what you actually did, instead of skipping steps all over like what I did in DSE.

    I had a friend asking me about a limit problem and I explained to him the arithmetic rule, and the composition rule, and he don't understand. He said: What are all those rules? I didn't use those rules and I got the answer anyways. I said: You said you didn't use it because you don't know you are using it. That's why you get things wrong. You just assumes things and blindly use it (like the L'Hopital's Rule). Taking MATH 1023 really made me more careful when doing problems.

    (Some contents actually overlap with MATH 2033 so if you have made your way to the end of 1023, you should have an easier time in that. Professor said that some of our content is actually harder.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
His teaching is good. He often make jokes in lectures which helped (at least) me focus. We often have breaks in between so we can digest what he just said and we can ask questions as well.

    One time he devoted the whole lecture talking about the application of IVT, albeit not quite related to the course, is definitely interesting if you like maths.

    Keep in mind that the homework is much more difficult than the lectures, and professor said that the learning really only begins in the homework.

    The tutorials are ok. Sometimes the TA prepared some questions that he have no idea how to solve, or need to use clueless complicated stuff to solve. And he sometimes can't finish the notes. There are good questions in the tutorial though.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 Schemes: 22% HW, 3% peer review ( if your reviews are ok and no one reported you then you should be fine), (35% Midterm and 40% Final) or (70% Final), whichever are higher. There are bonus if you type your homework in LaTeX (0.1 overall/homework), one bonus question (for the first five answered correctly),one bonus problem set (iPhone X eh I mean Problem set X) and some bonus if you give good reviews (idk who got it)

Midterm (over 100 marks,)
Mean: 55.07, Median:55.5, Highest: 100

Finals (over 100 marks,)
Mean: 65.47, Median: 64, Highest: 100 (6 students)

    For me, I got 69 marks in midterm and 89 marks in finals, so I actually used scheme B (the all-in-final scheme) and got an A. Nobody fails but one do get a D.

    But don't get fooled by the seeming good grade because you will get rekt by xue ba and IMO medalist! Only come if you really wanted to study (pure) math in the future (or if you are masochistic. In that case go for it! You do you!)
reviews.comment_workload:
If you feel like that this course is for you, then think twice. The workload is really heavy. Overall 9 problem sets (1 bonus problem set), and each consists of several computation problems (can be hard), and several high difficulty questions, then I can only say that no one can help you , not even google, except for our lord savior professor Fong or TAs.

    I spent at least 8-10 hours on each homework. (Almost) Every Thursday and Friday night I would be just hating my life, but finishing those questions give you that sense of satisfaction and joy (that's right) when you finally think of the trick needed, or done the question, that MATH 1003/1012/1013 would never be able to give you. Until next week and the cycle continues.

    If you want to pwn this course, what are you smoking? But if you really do, you really need to spend time into not only the homework, but also the problems in Prof. Yan's notes, which would help you clear your concepts and learn some tricks, and extra exercise from other references.

    If you think that you can overcome the homework (don't overlook their difficulty and time required!), then definitely take this course. You will not regret it.

    Oh and by the way, the midterms and finals are open-notes and you can bring 2 notebooks, and you can use a calculator as well! Not that any of that are useful, but hey. Copy down all homework solutions ( and digest them) and you will be set for both.

reviews.comment_workload:
如果说前面三项我给的评分还有余地，那么workload这一项是毫无疑问的E

今年的Homework并不是像往年那样以小组形式完成，而是需要你独立提交（当然，你可以与别人讨论，也可以去网上查，但是复制粘贴别人的作业一定是不可以的），这就直接造成了workload的翻倍

Professor Frederick is a well explainer. He is also efficient and organized that he like to post all the solutions immediately after the deadlines or the exams.

In terms of the teaching materials, Professor Frederick uses electronic hand-written slides (see the attachments) based on a 347-page lecture note written by Prof. Min YAN which even him does not read it. Also, there are lecture videos available in Canvas, which delay very often.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is very bad for DSE students, but consider a fact that most of the students get at least B-.

There are two marking schemes, and
Total score = max{Scheme A,Scheme B} + bonus points.
Scheme A: Assignment (22%) + Peer Review (3%) + Midterm Exam (35%) + Final Exam (40%) = Total (100%);
Scheme B: Assignment (22%) + Peer Review (3%) + Midterm Exam (0%) + Final Exam (70%) = Total (95%).

I personally knows the stuff in DSE extremely well, but still can't compensate the gap in between.
I am an Engineering student pre-registered MATH1013 but (I thought) my math is good enough, and somehow I swapped to MATH1023, and I now regret for the fucked up grade.
I get:
Assignment: 456/593 (76.9%)
Midterm Exam: 31/100 (Mean = 55.07, Median = 55.5)
Final Exam: 39/100 (Mean: 65.47, Median = 64)
Total: 47.52 (B-)

The exams are even more difficult than the assignments. (See the attachments.)

There are 6 IMO medalists (international students) in this year, they (probably they) get 100/100 (no typo!!) in the final exam. Almost 80% of other students are from China, that they learn most of the stuff in high school, winning in the beginning. (See the attachments.)

I strongly encourage, take the course if and only if:
1. you are an IMO medalist, or
2. you know HKAL Pure Math well (the style), or
3. you are going to study Math major.
Don't be faked by the M2 level 5 or above requirement.

I later on realize that I can actually stick to MATH1013 and study MATH1023 because their topic are similar in a way that MATH1023 students can handle MATH1013.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very heavy compared with other year 1 courses.

There is an assignment each week (or two weeks for the last 3 assignments), all in total of 10 assignments and the last one is optional, on average each consists of 5 problems selected from the lecture note in Part 1 (no marks but have penalty for not doing them) and 5 problems created by Professor Frederick in Part 2. The problems in Part 2 are very difficult that might be time consuming. (See the attachments.) I personally have no totally completed assignment.

reviews.comment_content:
内容偏向于证明，和1013的纯算数完全不是一个概念。
从数列极限开始，讲到函数极限，再引入导数，最后以泰勒展开收尾。每一个定理都会给出详细的证明（有些可能会当成作业让你自己证）。内容整体难度因人而异，但是即使你是竞赛生，还是要花不少时间在学习这门课的内容上的，因为实际上的内容跟竞赛没有太大关系（不像1312，竞赛生可以完全不听课）。
这门课对于培养严谨的数学思维非常有利，知其然还知其所以然。但是唯一的问题就是，这门课在学期结束的时候，并不会讲到积分，那个得留到1024。
reviews.comment_teaching: 方子豪（AKA，A0）的教学真的没话说。讲课非常的幽默，段子满天飞，基本每节课都是在欢声笑语中度过的，但是遗憾的是，因为疫情，只能上University of Zoom，没法当面感受A0的魅力。
reviews.comment_grading: 绝对龟，今年的龟给的其实不如往年，A- range大概只有1/3，A+更是只有6/120，对于一门相对难度这么大的荣誉堂而言，其实算是差的。主要问题在于期末出题太狗，而且想要拿A+必须得总分95以上（基本上就是考试不能犯大错）。还有，给一些喜欢跳步的同学一个忠告，千万不要跳步，每一步都要写清楚，把改卷老师当成傻子才能避免你不必要的丢分（本人期中期末都有presentation的扣分，而且都不少）。
reviews.comment_workload: 有人觉得很大，但是我个人觉得只要课都认真听了，其实不用花太多时间，因为很多东西都是他在课上讲过的东西的变形。但是今年不知道怎么回事，个人认为T课的题目难度远超作业题。
